Option A. Normal Calcium: In many cases of nutritional rickets, serum calcium levels are normal or low-normal at the time of presentation due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which compensates for the low calcium by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

Option B. Low Phosphate: Hypophosphatemia is common in rickets due to decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate and increased renal excretion.

 

Option D. High PTH: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs as a response to hypocalcemia, leading to elevated PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely tumor arising from the slide shown in the image?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma

 

The provided histopathological image shows multiple gland formations, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinomas are malignant tumors that arise from glandular epithelial cells. The presence of glandular structures in the histological slide is a key indicator of this type of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of carcinoma is characterized by the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, which are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of the lymphoid tissue and do not typically show glandular patterns in histology.

 

Option D. Sarcoma: Sarcomas arise from mesenchymal cells and are characterized by spindle-shaped cells. They do not exhibit glandular formations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is identified by the presence of glandular formations in histopathological slides.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to you with neuropathy in his bilateral lower limbs and a positive Romberg sign. He has a history of gastrectomy for stomach cancer. He is likely deficient in which of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

The case presents a classic scenario of Vitamin B12 deficiency due to gastrectomy. When a patient undergoes gastric surgery, there is a decrease in parietal cell mass, which leads to reduced secretion of both hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor. Intrinsic factor is crucial for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the terminal ileum.

 

Its deficiency leads to malabsorption of vitamin B12, resulting in neurological manifestations and Haematological Manifestations:

 

 Neurological Manifestations:

 

  • Neuropathy in bilateral lower limbs: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to demyelination of the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts, resulting in sensory loss and weakness.
  • Positive Romberg sign: This indicates impaired proprioception, which is a hallmark of subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord.
  • Other neurological symptoms: Tingling, numbness, gait disturbances, and even cognitive impairment.

 

Hematological Manifestations:

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia: Due to impaired DNA synthesis, leading to macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils on peripheral smear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because thiamine absorption occurs in the duodenum and is not dependent on intrinsic factor
  • Does not typically present with peripheral neuropathy as the primary manifestation

 

Option B. Folate deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because folate absorption is not dependent on intrinsic factor
  • While it can cause megaloblastic anemia, it does not cause neurological manifestations

 

Option D. Transferrin deficiency

 

  • Incorrect because transferrin is related to iron transport and is not primarily affected by gastrectomy
  • Does not cause neurological manifestations

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-gastrectomy patients are at high risk for Vitamin B12 deficiency due to lack of intrinsic factor production, leading to neurological manifestations like peripheral neuropathy, positive Romberg sign and megaloblastic anemia. Lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation is essential in such patients to prevent neurological and hematological complications.

 

 

Causes of B12 Deficiency

 

  1. Vegans
  2. At stomach level - Elderly/ gastrectomy / Pernicious anemia
  3. At pancreas level - Pancreatitis, hypofunctioning pancreas
  4.  At intestine level - Bacterial overgrowth syndrome, diverticulosis.
  5. At ileum level - Malabsorption disorders, GIT TB, Crohn's disease, fish tapeworm
  6. ↓ intake
  7. ↓ absorption - ↓ intrinsic factor – pernicious anemia
  8. ↑ requirement - Children, pregnancy, lactation

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of 2 months of amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is positive. On speculum examination, the following finding is observed. Identify the sign seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chadwick’s sign

 

The image shows a speculum examination of the cervix demonstrating a bluish/purplish discoloration, which is known as Chadwick's sign or Jacquemier's sign. This is one of the earliest visible signs of pregnancy, caused by increased vascularity and venous congestion of the cervix and vagina during early pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Osiander sign: This is incorrect. Osiander sign refers to the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity of uterine arteries in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Hegar sign: This is incorrect. Hegar sign is elicited during bimanual examination where there is softening of the lower uterine segment, allowing the examiner's fingers to almost meet between the cervix and uterine body.

 

Option D. Placental sign: This is incorrect. Placental sign refers to implantation bleeding that occurs when the embryo implants in the uterus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chadwick's sign (bluish discoloration of cervix and vagina) as one of the early visible signs of pregnancy during speculum examination, distinguishing it from other early pregnancy signs like Hegar's and Osiander's signs.
